conclusion: The reciprocal of the velocity of a particle moving in a straight line is shown as a function of its displacement x.
The graph of 1/v versus x is a straight line with a positive slope.

premise: The slope of the line in the graph represents the rate of change of 1/v with respect to x.
conclusion: If the slope is positive, as x increases, 1/v increases, implying v is decreasing.
Acceleration a can be expressed as the derivative of velocity v with respect to time t, i.e., a = dv/dt.
Velocity v is the derivative of displacement x with respect to time t, i.e., v = dx/dt.
Acceleration a can be expressed as a = v * dv/dx.

premise: 1/v is a linear function of x, written as 1/v = mx + c.

conclusion: Differentiating v with respect to x gives dv/dx = -m/(mx + c)^2.

premise: m is positive as the line has a positive slope.
conclusion: dv/dx is negative, indicating v decreases as x increases.

premise: The slope of the 1/v versus x graph is positive.
